section-block.ac_header-game-card: Behind the Curtain: Build a Tower

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials For this activity, you will need various colors of Connecting Cubes and a book or manila folder to serve as the “curtain.”

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Before we read Dad’s First Day, we learned the words first, second, and third. We stood in order and said which friend was first, second, or third in line.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Explain the Activity In this activity, you will make a tower of Connecting Cubes that matches the tower I build behind the curtain. I will tell you which cubes to put first, second, and third.
Revisit the Vocabulary Use the first Vocabulary Card to reteach the word.
Ask Can you make a tower to match mine? First, use a red cube. Second, use a blue cube. Third, use a green cube. Build this tower behind the curtain.

Extend Ask children to tell which color cube is first, second, and third in the tower using the sentence frame, The first/second/third cube is . Raise the curtain to check whether your towers are the same.
Repeat Continue using ordinal numbers in your directions to make towers behind the curtain.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: How can you tell which block is the second one? Show four cubes and point to the third. If we have four cubes, can the second block ever be this one?

section-block.ac_header-game-card: Behind the Curtain: Build a Tower

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Begin the activity without the “curtain.” Guide children to match your actions as you build a tower with three cubes. Ask them to identify which color you used first, second, and third.
Ask children to build a tower with three cubes behind the curtain. Have them use ordinal numbers to direct you to build a matching tower.

For children who may need language support, review color words and first, second, and third before you begin the activity. Guide children to repeat each word after you. Then, play a few rounds without the curtain so that children can match the words they hear to what they see.

Putting together the Connecting Cube towers requires some dexterity. If children are having difficulty manipulating the cubes, give them a tray or work mat and allow them to place their cubes in a row without connecting them. Encourage them to play with Connecting Cubes at other times during the day to continue to develop these skills.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: When we read Dad’s First Day, we talked about the order in which Daddy and Oliver did different things. We used words like first, second, and third to describe order.
We also learned the words frustrated and worried as we read. Let’s practice those words again before we do this activity. Use the frustrated and worried Vocabulary Cards to reteach the words.
You will line up in size order from smallest to largest. But this activity is special—you have to line up without talking!

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Ask Who is the smallest in our group? Who is the tallest? Have the children stand at the ends of an invisible spectrum. Now, without talking, the rest of you get in order by height. Try to help children without talking too.

Extend Now we can talk again! Let’s say what place in line each of us is standing in: first, second, third, fourth, fifth, or sixth. Help children use the correct ordinal number to say their place in line.
Repeat Ask children to say their place in line again, this time counting from the tallest person to the shortest.

Talk About Frustration How did it feel to do the activity without talking? Did you feel frustrated? What did you do when you felt frustrated? Help children articulate how they felt during the activity and ask for strategies they tried to alleviate their frustration. Point out examples of children who were able to tolerate their frustration and persist to complete the task.

Place three items on the table in line and point to each as you say the ordinal number that describes its place. Then have children repeat the ordinal numbers after you while pointing to the corresponding item.
After children stand in order, have them mix themselves up for 10 seconds. Ask children to say their new places in line using ordinal numbers.
For children who need more language support, model sentences that already contain the ordinal numbers. Say the sentences aloud:

If children struggle to compare heights, ask specific questions to help them focus on the steps involved in comparing. Who is taller, you or Classmate? So should you stand before Classmate or after Classmate?

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials For this activity, you will need Two-Color Counters.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Before we read Dad’s First Day, we learned some location words. Location words are words we use to describe where something is. In Dad’s First Day , the location words were behind, inside, and outside. Other location words we use a lot are over, under, next to, on, between, and beside.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Explain the Activity In this activity, I will show you an Activity Card and read aloud a clue that uses a location word. You will listen to the clue and put a counter on the part of picture that I describe on the Activity Card.
Ask Give each child two Two-Color Counters. Show one child the picture on the first Activity Card and read aloud the clue.
Extend Children can practice using location words by placing the counter on a different object in the picture and describing its placement: The yellow counter is below the table.
Repeat Continue the activity until every child plays with at least one Activity Card.
Talk About Locations What words gave you clues to know where to place the counter? Guide children to list the location words they heard as they played.

Help children differentiate among the location words by first modeling the term in context, and then having them place their counter on the Activity Card. For example, if the term on the Activity Card is under, place a counter under a book and say, The counter is under the book.
Help children name location words that have not been used. Challenge them to use those terms when giving clues to other students about where to place counters.

For children who need language support, use pointing to reinforce the location words. During Extend, encourage children, prompting words as needed. They can also name objects in their home languages to support vocabulary development.
If children have difficulty manipulating the Two-Color Counters, use red and yellow Connecting Cubes or other easier-to-pick-up manipulatives.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: When we read Our School Rules, we talked about rules in the school and how we can stay safe at school by following these rules.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Explain the Activity We will play Simon Says. I will be Simon, and I will tell you what action to do and you will do it. This game has only one rule: only do the action if I say to do it. Give several examples of saying “Simon Says” and just giving the direction without “Simon Says.” Once children understand the difference in the two directives, start playing!

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Simon Says, “clap your hands.” Simon Says, “clap your hands above your head.” Continue giving the children directions that incorporate a motion and a location word. Examples include, Put your finger under your chin. Put one hand behind your back. Touch the top of your head. Continue giving directions both with and without saying “Simon Says.”

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Extend Decide whether or not to play with elimination. If playing with elimination, have children sit if they “get out.” They can keep playing while sitting down.
Repeat Adjust the game slightly by playing really fast or asking a volunteer to be Simon.
Talk About Following Directions Have children talk about which location words are easier and harder to remember. Which directions were harder to follow? Which were easier?
Separate complex directions into two distinct actions: first point to a body part and then do the motion. Then repeat the direction combining the two actions.
Have children turn their backs to you as they play so you can’t influence their movements. Have them face forward once they think they are doing the correct motion.
For children who need language support, limit the body parts and motions to a distinct set. Review these terms before beginning to play.

For children who have difficulty doing full-body movements, modify the directions so they rely less on coordination and balance and more on an understanding of location words. Allow children to sit as they play and limit the moves to moving hands and arms only.
